question: What is HTML?
answer: HTML stands for HyperText Markup Language. It is the standard markup language for creating Web pages.
details: It describes the structure of a Web page using markup.

question: What is the purpose of <!DOCTYPE html>?
answer: It is a declaration to the browser that the document is an HTML5 document.
details: It prevents the browser from switching to 'Quirks Mode'.

question: What is the difference between <head> and <body>?
answer: <head> contains metadata (title, styles, scripts) not visible on the page. <body> contains the visible content.
details: The browser renders what is inside the body tag.

question: What are HTML attributes?
answer: Attributes provide additional information about HTML elements. They are always specified in the start tag.
details: Format: name="value".

details: Block elements stack vertically; inline elements align horizontally.

question: When should you use <div> vs <span>?
answer: Use <div> for grouping block-level elements (sections, layouts). Use <span> for styling parts of text or inline elements.
details: Div is a block container; Span is an inline container.

question: Why do we use <meta charset="UTF-8">?
answer: It specifies the character encoding for the HTML document to ensure text/symbols are displayed correctly.
details: UTF-8 covers almost all characters and symbols in the world.

question: How many heading tags are there in HTML?
answer: There are 6 heading tags from <h1> to <h6>.
details: <h1> is the most important/largest, <h6> is the least.

details: Browsers automatically add margin before and after a paragraph.

details: It is an empty element.

question: How do you add comments in HTML?
answer: Using syntax.
details: Comments are not displayed in the browser.

question: Difference between <strong> and <b>?
answer: <b> makes text bold for styling. <strong> implies semantic importance (often read with emphasis by screen readers).
details: Visually they look the same, but semantically they differ.

question: Difference between <em> and <i>?
answer: <i> is italic text (visual). <em> is emphasized text (semantic importance).
details: Use <em> for stress emphasis.

question: What is the <pre> tag used for?
answer: It defines preformatted text. It preserves both spaces and line breaks.
details: Displayed in a fixed-width font (usually Courier).

question: Why is the 'lang' attribute important in the <html> tag?
answer: It declares the language of the Web page, assisting search engines and screen readers.
details: Example: lang="en" for English.

question: What does the 'title' attribute do?
answer: It specifies extra information about an element, usually displayed as a tooltip on hover.
details: Can be used on almost any element.

question: What tag is used to create a thematic break or horizontal line?
answer: The <hr> tag.
details: Used to separate content visually.

question: Difference between <q> and <blockquote>?
answer: <q> is for short inline quotations. <blockquote> is for long block-level quotations.
details: Browsers usually indent blockquote.

question: What are the types of lists in HTML?
answer: Unordered List (<ul>), Ordered List (<ol>), and Description List (<dl>).
details: <ul> uses bullets, <ol> uses numbers/letters.

question: What are <dt> and <dd> tags?
answer: Used inside a Description List (<dl>). <dt> defines the term, <dd> describes the term.
details: Useful for glossaries or metadata.

question: How do you create a hyperlink?
answer: Using the anchor <a> tag with the href attribute.
details: href stands for Hypertext Reference.

question: What does target="_blank" do?
answer: It opens the linked document in a new window or tab.
details: Good for external links.

question: Difference between Absolute and Relative paths?
answer: Absolute path is the full URL (e.g., https://site.com/img.jpg). Relative path is relative to the current file (e.g., /img.jpg).
details: Relative is preferred for internal links.

question: How do you display an image?
answer: Using the tag with src attribute.
details: It is a self-closing tag.

question: Why is the 'alt' attribute important for images?
answer: It provides alternative text if the image fails to load and is crucial for screen readers (accessibility) and SEO.
details: Should describe the image content.

question: How do you add a favicon to a page?
answer: Using the <link> tag inside the <head> section.
details: Rel attribute must be 'icon'.

question: How do you create a link that opens an email client?
answer: Using 'mailto:' inside the href attribute.
details: Can also pre-fill subject.

question: How do you create a link to a specific part of the same page?
answer: Assign an 'id' to the section and link to it using '#id'.
details: This is called an anchor link.

question: What is the <figure> and <figcaption> element?
answer: <figure> wraps media content (like images) and <figcaption> provides a caption for it.
details: Semantic way to group images with text.

question: What is the purpose of the 'srcset' attribute?
answer: It allows defining multiple image sources for different screen sizes/resolutions (Responsive Images).
details: Browser picks the best fit.

question: What is the <picture> element?
answer: It gives more control than 'srcset' for responsive images, allowing different image formats or aspect ratios.
details: Contains tags and one tag.

question: What is an image map?
answer: An image with clickable areas defined by the <map> and <area> tags.
details: Links can be rectangular, circular, or polygonal.

question: How do you link an external CSS file?
answer: Using the <link> tag in the <head>.
details: Attributes: rel="stylesheet", href="style.css".

question: Where should the <script> tag be placed?
answer: Usually at the end of the <body> to prevent blocking page rendering, or in <head> with 'defer'/'async'.
details: If in head without defer, it pauses HTML parsing.

question: What is the difference between 'async' and 'defer' in script tags?
answer: 'async' downloads script in parallel and executes immediately (can break order). 'defer' downloads in parallel but executes after HTML parsing is complete (maintains order).
details: Use defer for dependent scripts.

question: How to set the viewport for responsive design?
answer: Using the meta viewport tag.
details: Controls layout on mobile browsers.

question: What is an <iframe>?
answer: An inline frame used to embed another document within the current HTML document.
details: Used for maps, videos, or external widgets.

question: How do you display reserved characters like '<' or '>'?
answer: Using HTML entities.
details: < is < and > is >

question: What tags are used to create a table?
answer: <table>, <tr> (row), <td> (data/cell), <th> (header).
details: <th> text is bold and centered by default.

question: What are <thead>, <tbody>, and <tfoot>?
answer: They group header content, body content, and footer content in a table.
details: Useful for styling and printing (header/footer repeat on pages).

question: What are colspan and rowspan?
answer: Attributes to merge cells. 'colspan' merges columns horizontally, 'rowspan' merges rows vertically.
details: Used in <td> or <th> tags.

question: What is the <form> element?
answer: It defines a section for user input.
details: Wraps input elements like text fields, checkboxes, buttons.

question: Difference between GET and POST methods?
answer: GET appends data to URL (visible, limited size). POST sends data in body (hidden, unlimited size, secure).
details: Use POST for sensitive data like passwords.

question: What is the <input> tag?
answer: The most used form element. Its behavior depends on the 'type' attribute.
details: Types: text, password, submit, radio, checkbox, etc.

question: Difference between Checkbox and Radio button?
answer: Checkbox (type="checkbox") allows selecting multiple options. Radio (type="radio") allows selecting only one from a group.
details: Radio buttons must share the same 'name' attribute to work as a group.

question: What is the <label> tag used for?
answer: It defines a label for an <input> element. Clicking the label focuses the input.
details: Link using 'for' attribute on label and 'id' on input.

question: What is the <select> and <option> tag?
answer: Used to create a drop-down list.
details: <select> contains multiple <option> elements.

question: How do you create a multi-line text input?
answer: Using the <textarea> element.
details: It is not an empty tag; it has a closing tag.

question: What is the <fieldset> and <legend>?
answer: <fieldset> groups related data in a form (draws a box). <legend> defines the caption for the fieldset.
details: Useful for organizing large forms.

question: Name some new input types introduced in HTML5.
answer: email, url, number, range, date, time, color, tel, search.
details: These provide built-in validation and mobile-friendly keyboards.

question: What does the 'placeholder' attribute do?
answer: It specifies a short hint that describes the expected value of an input field.
details: Disappears when the user types.

question: What is the 'required' attribute?
answer: It specifies that an input field must be filled out before submitting the form.
details: Browser prevents submission if empty.

question: How do you disable an input field?
answer: Using the 'disabled' attribute.
details: Disabled fields are not sent in the form submission.

question: What is the 'readonly' attribute?
answer: The field cannot be modified by the user, but the value IS sent on submission.
details: Difference from disabled: disabled is not sent.

question: What is the <datalist> element?
answer: It specifies a list of pre-defined options for an <input> element.
details: Provides an 'autocomplete' feature.

question: How do you handle file uploads in a form?
answer: Set input type="file" and form enctype="multipart/form-data".
details: Without this enctype, the file content is not sent.

question: What are the types of buttons?
answer: type="submit" (submits form), type="reset" (clears form), type="button" (no default action, used with JS).
details: Default type inside a form is submit.

question: What is a hidden input?
answer: An input field hidden from the user but sent with form submission.
details: Used for sending IDs or tokens.

question: What are Semantic Elements?
answer: Elements that clearly describe their meaning to both the browser and the developer (e.g., <header>, <footer>).
details: Non-semantic: <div>, <span>.

question: What is the <header> tag?
answer: Represents introductory content or a set of navigational links for a document or section.
details: Not to be confused with <head>.

question: What is the <nav> tag?
answer: Defines a set of navigation links.
details: Used for main menus.

question: Difference between <section> and <article>?
answer: <article> is independent, self-contained content (like a blog post). <section> is a thematic grouping of content.
details: Articles can contain Sections, and Sections can contain Articles.

question: What is the <aside> tag?
answer: Defines content aside from the content it is placed in (like a sidebar).
details: Usually related indirectly to surrounding content.

question: What is the <footer> tag?
answer: Defines a footer for a document or section.
details: Contains copyright, contact info, etc.

question: What is the <main> tag?
answer: Specifies the main content of a document.
details: Should be unique and not inside header/footer/nav.

question: What is the <time> tag?
answer: Defines a specific time (or datetime).
details: Machine-readable using 'datetime' attribute.

question: What is the <mark> tag?
answer: Defines marked/highlighted text.
details: Default style is yellow background.

question: How do you embed video in HTML5?
answer: Using the <video> tag.
details: Supports attributes like controls, autoplay, loop.

question: How do you embed audio in HTML5?
answer: Using the <audio> tag.
details: Similar to video tag.

question: What formats are supported by HTML5 Video?
answer: MP4, WebM, and Ogg.
details: MP4 is most widely supported.

question: What is the <canvas> element?
answer: A container used to draw graphics on the fly via JavaScript.
details: It is pixel-based (raster).

question: What is SVG?
answer: Scalable Vector Graphics. It defines graphics using XML.
details: It is vector-based (scales without losing quality).

question: Difference between Canvas and SVG?
answer: Canvas is pixel-based (JS drawing, good for games). SVG is vector-based (DOM elements, good for logos/charts).
details: SVG elements can have event handlers; Canvas is a single element.

question: What is the <embed> tag?
answer: Defines a container for an external resource, like a plug-in.
details: Less common now; object or iframe is preferred.

question: What is the <details> and <summary> tag?
answer: Used to create a collapsible widget. <summary> defines the visible heading.
details: User clicks summary to show/hide details.

question: What is the <progress> tag?
answer: Represents the completion progress of a task.
details: Displays a progress bar.

question: What is the <meter> tag?
answer: Defines a scalar measurement within a known range (like disk usage).
details: Different from progress (which indicates time/completion).

question: What is the 'sandbox' attribute in <iframe>?
answer: It applies extra restrictions to the content in the iframe (e.g., prevents scripts, forms).
details: Security feature.

question: What is the purpose of the Meta Description tag?
answer: It provides a brief summary of a web page. Search engines often display it in search results.
details: Critical for Click-Through Rate (CTR).

question: What are ARIA roles?
answer: ARIA (Accessible Rich Internet Applications) roles define the purpose of an element to screen readers (e.g., role="navigation").
details: Used when semantic HTML is insufficient.

question: What is the 'contenteditable' attribute?
answer: It specifies whether the content of an element is editable by the user.
details: Makes any element behave like a textarea.

question: What are 'data-' attributes?
answer: Custom attributes used to store extra data private to the page or application.
details: Accessible via JavaScript (dataset property).

question: What is the 'hidden' attribute?
answer: A boolean attribute that prevents the element from being displayed.
details: Functionally similar to CSS display: none.

question: Difference between localStorage and sessionStorage?
answer: localStorage persists even after browser is closed (no expiration). sessionStorage is lost when the tab/window is closed.
details: Both store key/value pairs in the browser.

question: What is the Geolocation API?
answer: An HTML5 API used to get the geographical position of the user.
details: Requires user permission.

question: What is HTML5 Drag and Drop?
answer: A standard way to drag and drop items. Elements must have draggable="true".
details: Involves events like ondragstart, ondrop.

question: What are Web Workers?
answer: JavaScript running in the background, separate from the main execution thread.
details: Allows heavy tasks without freezing the UI.

question: What are Server-Sent Events (SSE)?
answer: A standard allowing a web page to get updates from a server automatically (one-way messaging).
details: Uses the EventSource interface.

question: What is a WebSocket?
answer: A protocol providing full-duplex communication channels over a single TCP connection.
details: Real-time, two-way communication (Chat apps).

question: What is the Application Cache (AppCache) vs Service Workers?
answer: AppCache is deprecated. Service Workers are the modern standard for offline experiences and caching.
details: Service Workers act as a network proxy.

question: What is a Web App Manifest?
answer: A JSON file that provides information about an application (name, author, icon) for Progressive Web Apps (PWA).
details: Allows 'Add to Homescreen'.

question: What is the <address> tag?
answer: Defines contact information for the author/owner of a document or article.
details: Usually renders in italic.

question: What is Microdata?
answer: A specification to nest metadata within existing content on web pages (using itemprop, itemscope).
details: Helps search engines understand content better (Rich Snippets).

question: What is the 'download' attribute in anchor tags?
answer: It specifies that the target will be downloaded when a user clicks on the hyperlink.
details: You can also specify the filename.

question: What is Content Security Policy (CSP)?
answer: A security layer to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including XSS and data injection.
details: Defined via meta tag or HTTP header.

question: What is the <track> tag used for?
answer: Used within <video> and <audio> elements to specify subtitles or caption files.
details: Format is usually WebVTT.

question: What is the 'autofocus' attribute?
answer: It specifies that an input element should automatically get focus when the page loads.
details: Only one element per page should have this.

question: What is Quirks Mode vs Standards Mode?
answer: Standards Mode renders strict HTML/CSS specifications. Quirks Mode emulates older browser behaviors for backward compatibility.
details: Triggered by the presence or absence of !DOCTYPE.
